reasoning: The critique targets an important sub-argument in §3.2: that linear/separable moral views make mostly-great futures a narrow target because (i) there is effectively a single value-efficient local arrangement to replicate and (ii) the space of uses is so large that near-optimal uses are rare. If this inference failed, Forethought’s claim that linear views are fussy would be weakened, but the overall “no easy eutopia” conclusion has multiple independent supports (eutopian fragility/product-of-factors in §2; fussiness of many bounded views in §3.3; moral uncertainty considerations), so it wouldn’t collapse. On strength, the objection correctly notes a logical gap: separability/additivity does not entail uniqueness or small measure of near-maximizers, and large symmetry/degeneracy classes could make ‘almost optimal per resource’ common. However, it only partially undercuts the paper because the paper’s core driver for narrowness is the additional (defeasible) empirical/structural claim of a fat-tailed value-efficiency distribution; the critique gestures at, but doesn’t provide, reasons to expect thick near-optimal sets under realistic constraints. Relevance is fairly high because it engages a key Tier-2 Forethought assumption/argument about why even “good” surviving futures likely miss most value, and it points to a concrete place where an extra argument (about the measure/volume of near-optimal configurations) would be needed.
title: "Vast Spaces of Near-Optimal Arrangements"
